body_text.text: To increase bed capacity and resources, hospitals have postponed elective surgeries, although the 07 financial impact of this decision is unknown. We sought to report elective surgical case distribution, 08 associated gross hospital earnings and regional hospital and intensive care unit (ICU) bed capacity 09 as elective surgical cases are cancelled and then resumed under simulated trends of COVID-19 10 incidence. 11 12
body_text.section: Background: 06

body_text.text: A retrospective, cohort analysis was performed using insurance claims from 161 million enrollees 14 from the MarketScan database from January 1, 2008 to December 31, 2017. COVID-19 cases were 15 calculated using a generalized Richards model. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reports on the 16 number of hospitalized and intensive care patients by age were used to estimate the number of cases 17 seen in the ICU, the reduction in elective surgeries and the financial impact of this from historic claims 18 data, using a denominator of all inpatient revenue and outpatient surgeries. 19 20
body_text.section: Methods: 13

body_text.text: Assuming 5% infection prevalence, cancelling all elective procedures decreases ICU overcapacity 22 from 340% to 270%, but these elective surgical cases contribute 78% (IQR 74, 80) (1.1 trillion (T) US 23 dollars) to inpatient hospital plus outpatient surgical gross earnings per year. Musculoskeletal, 24 circulatory and digestive category elective surgical cases compose 33% ($447B) of total revenue. 25 26
body_text.section: Results: 21

body_text.text: Procedures involving the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular and digestive system account for the 28 largest loss of hospital gross earnings when elective surgery is postponed. As hospital bed capacity 29 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. body_text.section: Competing interests 57

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 4, 2020. with resultant excess morbidity and mortality [3] . Current estimates suggest 5% of the US population 88 will contract COVID-19, of whom 15% will require hospitalization, and 5% will require intensive care 89 [4] [5] [6] . At this rate, there will be 5 infected patients requiring hospitalization for every existing US 90 hospital bed in addition to concomitant hospitalized non-COVID patients [7] . 91
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: In order to decrease the resources needed during the peak of COVID-19, many countries have 93 United States has emphasized physical distancing and suspension of non-essential business 97 operations which have, until now, included elective surgical procedures. This has resulted in 98 hospitals in areas with relatively few COVID-19 patients, such as Utah, functioning at only 30% of 99 their typical inpatient and surgical capacity. The financial implications of cancelling elective surgical 00 procedures has been devastating for healthcare systems with some systems currently losing upwards 01 of $25 million USD per week [9] . 02 03 However, to mitigate large anticipated surges in hospitalizations and deaths over the coming months, 04

US hospitals need to sustainably absorb increases in patients requiring hospitalization and intensive 05 care, while continuing to care for non-COVID patients. After a statement from the American College 06 of Surgeons (ACS), many hospitals across the country ceased elective surgery to free beds and limit 07 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 4, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.29.20066506 doi: medRxiv preprint patient exposure. While cancelling elective surgical cases has increased capacity, the financial 08 impact of these surgeries, including relative financial contribution by case type, has not been 09 described. Furthermore, the epidemiology of the deferred elective surgical cases, case counts, and 10 their resultant contribution to bed capacity has not been described. 11
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: We estimate the financial implications of cancelling elective surgeries using a national insurance 13 claim database, Truven MarketScan (MS). This information can be used to inform strategies for 14 resuming elective surgical procedures. We describe regional differences in capacity of US hospitals is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.
The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 4, 2020.

body_text.text: In order to estimate the financial implications of cancelling or resuming elective surgical cases, we 54 calculated the distribution of gross earnings by MDC code and then by elective and non-elective 55 surgical, and non-surgical classifications. To inform the balance of revenue and capacity generation, 56
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis 53

body_text.text: we illustrate the effect of cancellation of elective surgical cases on hospital capacity by modeling a 57 scenario that may exist if 5% of the US population were infected with COVID-19. We constructed a 58 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis 53

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 4, 2020. . https://doi.org/10. 1101 /2020 Generalized Richards Growth Model (GRM), which has been proven effective for capturing single 59 epidemic transmission dynamics, to describe a scenario that could happen in the absence of 60 limitation to the disease spread [14] . Our GRM assumed a 5% infection rate, 5.2-day doubling rate, 61 and 100-day period of disease progression. These values were based on current published rates and 62 do not account for variation in social distancing [15, 16] . 63
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: We illustrated gross earnings by MDC code and by classification. We calculated the number of 65 hospitalized patients in each state during the simulated pandemic peak using 11-day inpatient and 9-66 day ICU length of stay [5, 6, 17] . We then calculated the ratio of cases to total number of available 67 beds per state with and without removal of elective surgery. sample. Roughly 30% of these days were associated with elective surgery (Figure 1) Figure 2) . Within each MDC, the percent of earnings from elective surgical cases varies from <27% 82 to 97% (median 68%; IQR 53, 86). When restricting our analyses to inpatient-derived revenue, 83 elective surgery accounted for 43% (IQR of statewide variation 40, 45) of total gross earnings, or 84 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 4, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 /2020 $254B. This value varies by MDC from <1% to 88%, ($25M to $80B). The relative financial 85 contribution of elective surgical cases varies regionally and has important financial implications for 86 hospital specific decisions on resumption of these elective procedures (Figure 3) Cancelling elective surgeries adds significant capacity for new daily ICU admits (Figure 4A ), but falls 00 short of the full capacity required when 5% of the population is infected over a relatively short period 01 of time and median ICU length of stay is 9 days (Figure 4B) (Figure 4C ). If we use the UB rates of 08 ICU provided by the CDC, this increases to mean 8.2 patients per bed (IQR: 6.33 -9.67) ( Figure  09   4E ). Removing elective surgeries will alleviate some of this stress, with LB estimates of an average of 10 . body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Using billing and utilization data to model the financial contribution of elective surgical cases to 15 hospital gross earnings, we demonstrate that cessation of elective musculoskeletal, cardiovascular 16
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: and digestive cases account for the largest loss of hospital gross earnings, at $447B or 33% of all 17 inpatient and surgical-outpatient revenue. In contrast, by case count, musculoskeletal, pregnancy, 18 and circulatory categories account for the greatest contribution of elective inpatient cases. Applying 19 case counts to the available hospital beds, cancelling elective surgeries at all US hospitals will 20 decrease ICU overcapacity from 340% to 270% (lower bound) or from 820% to 640% (upper bound) 21 assuming 5% of the U.S. population is infected as shown in our models, but at a financial cost. In light 22
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: of the significant contribution of elective surgeries to gross hospital earnings, selective resumption of 23 high contributing elective MDC categories may be a way to resume surgery in a financially 24 sustainable way when deemed safe. 25 26 Continued provision of care to patients with COVID-19 involves balancing increasing healthcare 27 capacity with sustaining revenue generation. Previous models have addressed the expected 28 healthcare burden of COVID-19 in various ways, but have not addressed revenue generation. To our 29 knowledge, ours is the first to report case distribution and financial contribution of elective surgeries. 30
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: We incorporated state specific billing data, reporting the relative contribution of elective surgeries to 31 gross hospital earnings, and case counts, by MDC code. Our study informs the relative financial and 32 capacity impact from selective resumption of elective cases. Further, we model the expected increase 33 in bed capacity from cancelling these surgeries. Tsai et al previously estimated 1.7 excess COVID-19 34 patients per hospital bed and 4 excess patients per critical care bed assuming a 40% cumulative 35 infection rate over 12 and 18 months, and an aggressive 50% bed availability [18] . Similarly, Murry 36 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 4, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 /2020 used occupancy data from Medicare and Medicaid patients to estimate a capacity gap of 17,000 ICU 37 beds and 64,000 hospital beds at peak infection assuming some measure of social distancing [19] . 38
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Our study differs from these by modeling disease transmission under a lower infection rate (5%) but 39 faster course (100 days) than Tsai et al, and in a worse-case scenario without complete shelter in 40 place orders, which 9 states do not currently have [20] . We also incorporated state-specific data for 41 elective case volume and temporal variation. We demonstrated substantial state-level variation in 42 overcapacity. This suggests an opportunity for regional cooperation and resource redistribution. 43
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Our results are generated using a financial denominator of total inpatient revenue plus outpatient 45 surgical cases, and do not account for the Medicare population that is not insured by Part C. We 46 determined overcapacity values using consistent rates of infection across the population in less than 47 100 days and assumptions that regional rates are equal [7, 18, 19] . It is important to note that we 48 applied rates of disease progression from regions prior to enforced distancing. Consistent with this, 49

we assumed a stable rate of disease progression of 100 days since first case and do not account for 50 policy responses to the pandemic, such as closure of non-essential service and stay-at-home orders, 51 which are highly variable across states. 52

Elective inpatient surgeries account for and account 27% of hospital and ICU beds and 43% of gross 55 earnings, which varies substantially by specialty. Among elective cases, musculoskeletal, 56 cardiovascular and digestive MDC categories account for the largest contribution to hospital gross 57 earnings, at 33%. The greatest contribution of bed capacity comes from musculoskeletal, pregnancy 58 and circulatory categories. The cancellation of elective surgery will result in a substantial increase in 59 hospital and ICU bed capacity, though this will vary between states, and at significant financial cost. 60 61 62 . FIGREF3.text: 15 to absorb COVID-related inpatient surges if measures are not taken to slow the spread, describe 16 elective case distribution, and present the relative financial impact and case counts of resumption of 17 elective surgical cases. 18 19 METHODS 20 Our analysis is reported according to the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in 21 Epidemiology (STROBE) Guidelines (Supplemental Methods) [10]. 22 23 Data Source and Study Population 24 Gross inpatient hospital earnings, outpatient surgical earnings, and inpatient and ICU (I/ICU) beds 25 were estimated using Truven MarketScan (MS). MS billing data captured 8-16% of the entire US 26 population from 2013-2017. For every MS patient, we determined the total number of I/ICU days from 27 2008-2017 for 161 million (M) enrollees and aggregated visit counts by month, state, and major 28 diagnostic category (MDC). Elective surgery admissions were identified by surgery revenue codes not 29 associated with emergency revenue or provider codes. Admissions occurring within 30 days post-30 elective (including outpatient) surgery were considered complications and categorized as resulting 31 from elective surgery. Gross earnings were aggregated by MDC codes and surgical (elective vs non-

The dotted lines represent estimates of the number of patients 91 admitted into ICUs from the time the first person was infected and modeled for 100 days after this 92 based on a Generalized Richards Growth Model (GRM). The low and high estimates for COVID-19 93 infection are based on the CDC low and high estimates. Panels C-F: Impact of Cancelling All 94 Elective OR Cases on ICU Bed Availability if 5% of U.S. Population Infected with COVID-19. 95 Estimates of low (Panel C) and high (Panel E) ICU cases are derived the uncertainty estimates from 96 CDC MMWR reports from the CDC COVID-19 Response Team. Additional capacity through 97 cancellation of elective cases (Panel D, Panel F) was determined by applying estimates of the 98 occupied and unoccupied beds resulting from elective surgery from the Marketscan database to the 99Harvard Global Health Institute (HGHI) estimates of total inpatient and ICU beds in each state.

TABREF1.text: resulted in over 2.5 million infections worldwide[2]. United States (US) health systems are designed 84 for stable, predictable utilization patterns; they are generally unprepared for surge medical need as is 85 required with the COVID-19 pandemic. Surge situations have historically been addressed by 86 deploying temporary medical teams and tent facilities, or have overwhelmed the available resources 87

Analysis by MDC excluded eye, human immunodeficiency virus, health 33 MS data were used to report gross hospital earnings derived from inpatient admissions and outpatient 37 surgeries for each MDC category by elective vs non-elective surgical and non-surgical. We calculated 38proportion of gross earnings from elective surgeries by state, and the proportion of I/ICU beds 39 unoccupied, and occupied by elective and emergent cases by state. The average number of 40 unoccupied beds was defined as the difference between the average number of I/ICU days and the 41 maximum number of I/ICU days in a given state. We used data from the Harvard Global Health 42 Institute (HGHI) to identify the total number of I/ICU patient beds per state and applied the proportion 43 from the MS data to obtain estimates of occupied beds[11]. 44The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) was used to 46 calculate the number of expected I/ICU beds occupied by age group[12]. We applied these age-47 specific rates to 5% of each state's population using 2018 U.S. Census Bureau age-specific 48 population estimates to calculate the number of expected hospitalizations and inpatient cases by 49 state[13]. We calculated lower bound (LB) and upper bound (UB) estimates based on the CDC's 50
